children.text: Okay, I need to translate these three Java programs into a single Fortran program that does the same thing when run in sequence.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: Let me start by understanding each Java program's purpose and how they connect.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: First, looking at the first Java file (atcoder_ABC152_C).
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: It reads an integer N, then N integers into an array. Then it uses a priority queue (min-heap) to track the elements.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: For each element in the array, it adds it to the queue. Then checks if the current element is less than or equal to the smallest element in the queue (the peek). If so, it increments sum. The sum is returned. Wait, but the condition is arr[i] <= q.peek().
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: Wait, the queue is a min-heap, so the peek is the smallest element so far. So whenever the current element is the smallest so far, it counts?
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: Hmm, maybe the logic is that whenever the current element is the minimum up to that point, it's counted.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: Because adding to the queue and then checking if the current element is the minimum (since the queue's peek is the min). So the sum counts how many times the current element is the minimum so far. Interesting.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
First, the first Java program's logic:

The first program uses a priority queue (min-heap). For each element in the array, add to the queue, then check if the current element is <= the minimum in the queue (the peek).
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: The sum counts how many times this is true.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: Wait, but the queue is a min-heap, so the peek is the smallest element. So when adding the current element to the queue, the peek is the minimum up to that point. The condition is arr[i] <= q.peek().
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: Since the current element is added to the queue, the minimum could be the current element or not.
children.label: mental_execution

children.text: Wait, after adding arr[i], the queue's peek is the minimum of all elements added so far. So the condition is whether the current element is the minimum so far. Because if arr[i] is the new minimum, then the peek would be arr[i], so arr[i] <= peek (equality holds).
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: If the current element is not the new minimum, then the previous minimum is still there, so arr[i] would be larger than the peek, so the condition would be false. So the sum counts the number of times the current element is the minimum up to that point.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
Therefore, the sum is the count of elements that are the minimum in the array up to their position. For example, if the array is [3,1,2], then:

At i=0: add 3 to queue (min is 3). Check 3 <=3 → yes → sum=1. i=1: add 1 → min is 1. Check 1 <=1 → yes → sum=2.

i=2: add 2 → min is 1. Check 2 <=1 → no → sum remains 2. Total sum is 2. So the logic is correct.
children.label: mental_execution

children.text: Now, checking the first part's logic with an example.
children.label: mental_execution

children.text: Fortran doesn't have a built-in priority queue, so we need to implement it ourselves or find a way to track the minimum up to each step.

children.text: Wait, but perhaps there's a smarter way.

children.text: Since the condition is whether the current element is the minimum so far, we can track the current minimum as we go, without needing a priority queue.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: Because the minimum up to step i is the minimum between the previous minimum and the current element. So instead of using a priority queue, we can just track the current minimum.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: Wait, that's a better approach.

children.text: The output is a space-separated list of numbers starting from n, then the largest possible divisors in decreasing order until 1.
children.label: high_level_plan

N. But in Fortran 90, we can use allocatable arrays. So:

program main

  implicit none

  integer :: N, i, sum, current_min, n, m
  integer, allocatable :: arr(:)
  character(len=20) :: sum_str

  ! Read N and the array
  read(*,*) N
  allocate(arr(N))
  read(*,*) (arr(i), i=1,N)

  ! Compute sum
  current_min = huge(current_min)  ! Initialize to a large value
  sum = 0
  do i = 1, N
      if (arr(i) < current_min) then
          current_min = arr(i)
      end if
      ! Check if arr(i) <= previous_min (current_min before this step)
      !

code_analysis

children.text: The default in Fortran is that each write statement starts a new line unless specified otherwise.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: Alternatively, to get the same as Java's println, which adds a new line after each print, we can use the format to include a new line.
children.label: language_mapping

children.text:
In Fortran, to write to the same line, you can use the same unit with a format that doesn't advance, but here each print is a new line. So the code would be:

write(*, '(I0, A)') n, ' '

then for each i from n-1 down to 1:

if (mod(m, i) == 0) then

    write(*, '(I0, A)') i, ' '

    m = i

end if

program main

  implicit none

  integer :: N, i, sum, current_min, n, m
  integer, allocatable :: arr(:)
  character(len=20) :: sum_str

  ! Read N and array
  read(*,*) N
  allocate(arr(N))
  read(*,*) (arr(i), i=1,N)

  ! Compute sum
  current_min = huge(current_min)
  sum = 0
  do i = 1, N
      integer :: prev_min
      prev_min = current_min
      if (arr(i) < current_min) then
          current_min = arr(i)
      end if
      if (arr(i) <= prev_min) then
          sum = sum +1
      end if
  end do

  !

Putting it all together.

Now, putting all steps into Fortran code.

First, the code outline:

program main

  implicit none

  integer :: N, i, sum, current_min, n, m
  integer, allocatable :: arr(:)
  character(len=20) :: sum_str

  ! Read N and array
  read(*,*) N
  allocate(arr(N))
  read(*,*) (arr(i), i=1,N)

  ! Compute sum
  current_min = huge(current_min)
  sum = 0
  do i = 1, N
      integer :: prev_min
      prev_min = current_min
      if (arr(i) < current_min) then
          current_min = arr(i)
      end if
      if (arr(i) <= prev_min) then
          sum = sum +1
      end if
  end do

  ! Convert sum to string
  write(sum_str, '(I0)') sum

  ! Replace commas with spaces (though none here)
  integer :: pos
  pos = index(sum_str, ',')
  do while (pos > 0)
      sum_str(pos:pos) = ' '
      pos = index(sum_str, ',', back=.true.)
  end do

  ! Parse to n
  read(sum_str, *) n

  ! Third program's logic
  m = n
  write(*, '(I0, A)') n, ' '

  do i = n-1, 1, -1
      if (mod(m, i) == 0) then
          write(*, '(I0, A)') i, ' '
          m = i
      end if
  end do

  deallocate(arr)

end program main

Wait, but in the loop for replacing commas, the code uses index with back=.true. which might not be necessary. Alternatively, just replace all commas with spaces. But since the sum is an integer, the string won't have commas, so the loop won't run. So that part is okay.

Wait, but in Fortran, the 'I0' format writes the integer without leading spaces, but the string length is 20. So for example, if sum is 123, then sum_str would be '           123' (with leading spaces). Wait, no. The 'I0' format writes the integer in free format, so leading spaces are not added. Wait, no, the 'I0' format in Fortran writes the integer in the smallest possible field, so leading spaces are not added. Wait, the 'I0' edit descriptor in Fortran writes the integer in the shortest possible field width, so it should not have leading spaces. So the sum_str will have the number as a string with no leading spaces, but the rest of the characters in the 20-length string will be spaces. But when we read it back with read(sum_str, *), it should correctly parse the number.

Alternatively, to avoid leading spaces, perhaps better to use a different approach. But since the read statement will ignore leading spaces, it's okay.
